title: A Study of Various Activating Mutations and Conditions of the Epithelial Sodium Channel
A Study of Various Activating Mutations and Conditions of the Epithelial Sodium Channel
text:
1.1 Level 2 header
Presumably this is a section?


Can I put content in the margin in a quarto book? And can that content have a citation in it1
So now, if I cite a paper (maybe I’d cite our own), it appears in the margin2? OK, that doesn’t seem to work. But I’ll leave this anyway. Is it throwing an error just because there’s nothing after it? Maybe I need to fill in a bunch of space to give room?

title: 2  Summary
text: In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: 1  Introduction
text: Before diving into the findings of the present work, it’s essential to understand why we study ENaC and what we already knew both about its function and its structure. A brief overview of how single-particle analysis works will be useful for justification of mutations and conditions selected in the pursuit of the TMD. I therefore begin this chapter with a brief history of the evolution of ENaC and its relatives, what we know of ENaC’s processing and function, and the prior art with regards to its function.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 What does ENaC do?
ENaC is the rate-limiting step of sodium reabsorption in apical membranes of many tissues, including kidney, lung, colon, reproductive tract1–7.




1. Palmer, L.G. (1982). Ion selectivity of the apical membrane Na channel in the toad urinary bladder. The Journal of Membrane Biology 67, 91–98. 10.1007/BF01868651.


2. Hummler, E., Barker, P., Gatzy, J., Beermann, F., Verdumo, C., Schmidt, A., Boucher, R., and Rossier, B.C. (1996). Early death due to defective neonatal lung liquid clearance in αENaC-deficient mice. Nature Genetics 12, 325–328. 10.1038/ng0396-325.


3. Asher, C., Wald, H., Rossier, B.C., and Garty, H. (1996). Aldosterone-induced increase in the abundance of Na+ channel subunits. American Journal of Physiology-Cell Physiology 271, C605–C611. 10.1152/ajpcell.1996.271.2.C605.


4. Epple, H.J., Amasheh, S., Mankertz, J., Goltz, M., Schulzke, J.D., and Fromm, M. (2000). Early aldosterone effect in distal colon by transcriptional regulation of ENaC subunits. American Journal of Physiology-Gastrointestinal and Liver Physiology 278, G718–G724. 10.1152/ajpgi.2000.278.5.G718.


5. Enuka, Y., Hanukoglu, I., Edelheit, O., Vaknine, H., and Hanukoglu, A. (2012). Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are uniformly distributed on motile cilia in the oviduct and the respiratory airways. Histochemistry and Cell Biology 137, 339–353. 10.1007/s00418-011-0904-1.


6. Büsst, C.J. (2013). Blood pressure regulation via the epithelial sodium channel: From gene to kidney and beyond. Clinical and Experimental Pharmacology and Physiology 40, 495–503. 10.1111/1440-1681.12124.


7. Rossier, B.C., Baker, M.E., and Studer, R.A. (2015). Epithelial Sodium Transport and Its Control by Aldosterone: The Story of Our Internal Environment Revisited. Physiological Reviews 95, 297–340. 10.1152/physrev.00011.2014.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Blood Pressure and ENaC
Hypertension is one of the leading causes of preventable, premature death in the world1,2. It should come as no surprise, then, that the mechanisms by which the human body regulates blood pressure have been studied for decades. Researchers quickly demonstrated that the kidney is the essential organ for both medium- and long-term control of blood pressureguyton91?. The balance of fluid and salt excreted by the kidneys into the urine directly controls the total blood volume, and thus blood pressure. The mechanism most germane to this work is the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
Reduced fluid flow or sodium content induce the kidney to release the protease renin. Renin converts angiotensinogen into angiotensin I, which is in turn converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE). Angiotensin II has wide ranging effects on the circulatory system, but the most relevant here is the increased release of aldosterone from the adrenal glands. Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid steroid hormone which, among many other effects, increases expression of ENaC. Finally, we arrive at ENaC’s role in blood pressure regulation: as the main point of control for sodium reabsorption in the kidneylifton01?.




1. Lim, S.S., Vos, T., Flaxman, A.D., Danaei, G., Shibuya, K., Adair-Rohani, H., Amann, M., Anderson, H.R., Andrews, K.G., Aryee, M., et al. (2012). A comparative risk assessment of burden of disease and injury attributable to 67 risk factors and risk factor clusters in 21 regions, 1990-2010: A systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010. Lancet 380, 2224–2260. 10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61766-8.


2. Mills, K.T., Bundy, J.D., Kelly, T.N., Reed, J.E., Kearney, P.M., Reynolds, K., Chen, J., and He, J. (2016). Global Disparities of Hypertension Prevalence and Control: A Systematic Analysis of Population-Based Studies From 90 Countries. Circulation 134, 441–450. 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.115.018912.
